questions.question: ………………….. the footsteps, the thief ran away.
questions.description: The present participle is used to combine two clauses when they refer to actions that happen simultaneously.

questions.question: The poor man ……………………. very hungry ate the food greedily.
……………………….. his muscle power, he was defeated by his opponent.
questions.description: In spite of is a preposition. Use it before a noun.

questions.question: ……………………. a cripple, he cannot walk.
questions.description: He is a cripple. He cannot walk. Here we can replace is with being and write 'Being a cripple, he cannot walk.'

questions.question: …………………………. himself in deep debt, he decided to sell his home.
questions.description: He found himself in deep debt. He decided to sell his home. We can connect these two sentences using finding.

questions.question: In the event of such a thing ………………………, I will quit.
He intends to make another attempt ……………………….. his repeated failures.
questions.description: Either despite or notwithstanding can be used here.

questions.question: …………………………. my best efforts, I could not succeed.
………………………. pity for the mouse, the magician turned it into a cat.
………………………….. dissatisfied, he resigned his job.
questions.description: He was dissatisfied. He resigned his job. We can replace was with being. Being dissatisfied, he resigned his job.

questions.question: …………………….. the message, he departed.
questions.description: When one action follows another action, we can express that idea with a perfect participle.
